slides.ocrText: Assigning Activities

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe primary assignment
¢ Assign an activity

slides.originalNotes:
Primary versus role-based assignment
Guidewire refers to certain business entities as assignable entities. There are tvo types of assignable entities: Primary vs Role Based. To be primarily assignable, an entity must implement Assignable and PCAssignable delegates, which provide methods and fields needed for assignment. The Activity entity implements the Assignable and PCAssignable delegates.

A Delegate data object is a reusable entity that contains an interface and a default implementation of that interface. This permits an entity to implement an interface while delegating the implementation of that interface to another class, that of the delegate. You often use a delegate with objects that share code. The delegate implements the code rather than each class duplicating the shared code. Thus, a delegate is an entity associated with an implemented interface that multiple parent entities can reuse.
slides.notes:
Primary versus role-based assignment
Guidewire refers to certain business entities as assignable entities. There are tvo types of assignable entities: Primary vs Role Based. To be primarily assignable, an entity must implement Assignable and PCAssignable delegates, which provide methods and fields needed for assignment. The Activity entity implements the Assignable and PCAssignable delegates.

A Delegate data object is a reusable entity that contains an interface and a default implementation of that interface. This permits an entity to implement an interface while delegating the implementation of that interface to another class, that of the delegate. You often use a delegate with objects that share code. The delegate implements the code rather than each class duplicating the shared code. Thus, a delegate is an entity associated with an implemented interface that multiple parent entities can reuse.
slides.ocrText:
i Primary versus role-based assignment

¢ Primary assignment (discussed in
this lesson)

* The entity can have a single owner only

* In the base configuration, this applies to
Activity entities

¢ Role-based assignment

* The entity has a set of users — with different
roles — assigned to it

* In the base configuration, this applies to
Account, Job (and its subtypes), and
Policy entities

slides.originalNotes:
Typical flow of assignment execution
The diagram shows a typical flow of execution through assignment rules. The diagram omits processing that is required for error checking or atypical situations. The omitted processing is discussed later in this lesson. 

There are two assignment circumstances:
Neither a user nor group is specified: In this case, global assignment rules are executed first. Typically, global assignment rules assign the object to a group only, not to a user. Afterwards, default group assignment rules are executed to assign the object to a user within the assigned group. (In some cases, global assignment rules can assign the object to both a group and a user in the group. In this case, default group assignment rules are skipped.)
A group and user have been specified: In this case, no rules are run. The object is simply assigned to the specified user and group.
slides.notes:
Typical flow of assignment execution
The diagram shows a typical flow of execution through assignment rules. The diagram omits processing that is required for error checking or atypical situations. The omitted processing is discussed later in this lesson. 

There are two assignment circumstances:
Neither a user nor group is specified: In this case, global assignment rules are executed first. Typically, global assignment rules assign the object to a group only, not to a user. Afterwards, default group assignment rules are executed to assign the object to a user within the assigned group. (In some cases, global assignment rules can assign the object to both a group and a user in the group. In this case, default group assignment rules are skipped.)
A group and user have been specified: In this case, no rules are run. The object is simply assigned to the specified user and group.

slides.originalNotes:
Activity ownership
An activity can be assigned to a queue rather than a user. The group associated with the queue will be the group assigned to the activity. Similarly, the group assigned to an activity assigned to a user will generally be the user's primary group.

Sometimes an activity will briefly be assigned to just a group, but this is a transient state on the way to assigning to a user or queue.
Under no circumstances should you configure the application so that an entity is assigned at the same time to both a queue and a user.
slides.notes:
Activity ownership
An activity can be assigned to a queue rather than a user. The group associated with the queue will be the group assigned to the activity. Similarly, the group assigned to an activity assigned to a user will generally be the user's primary group.

Sometimes an activity will briefly be assigned to just a group, but this is a transient state on the way to assigning to a user or queue.
Under no circumstances should you configure the application so that an entity is assigned at the same time to both a queue and a user.
slides.ocrText:
i Activity ownership Gi

« An activity is owned by (assigned to) both a user and a group
* The assigned user must be a member of the assigned group
« Assigning “just” a user also assigns that user’s default group

¢ When an activity is assigned to a user:
+ It appears in that user's My Activities desktop list

* It can be edited only by that user (or other users with appropriate permissions, such as the
owner's supervisor)

¢ It can be viewed by other users in the group

slides.originalNotes:
Activity assignment
Activity assignment in Policy Center is configurable and can be configured by configuration users to meet carrier requirements- The base configuration activity assignment logic is quite simple and usually assigns activity using round robin within a group. Often carriers may want complex logic because they do not just want to assign activity to any Underwriter but to a foreign language speaking Underwriter for example- Another example would be to assign an under mriter  has familiarity with the LOB or type/magnitude of risks on the policy, rather than just one that is in a specific geographic area- Or they want to assign an underwriter that is more senior because of the client's tier or other measure of value to the insurer.

If it were configured for the insurer, which it isn't in the default configuration, the same kind of thing would apply for a loss- control inspector, or the like-
In Policy Center, most of the functions are assigned to someone who has a specific role on the policy. The easiest way to do this is you define the activity pattern which defines how it will be assigned, that's backed by a set of classes. You configure activity assignment in these classes. For example, you can assign the activity to the producer or an underwriter- If you are in a situation where you need more sophisticated assignment, then you can add a new role and then configure activity assignment for that role using one of the base classes to meet the specific business requirements.

slides.ocrText:
i Activity assignment

In PolicyCenter, an activity is assigned by:

+ Assignment rules, or > 8s"

« Assignment classes, or

* Combination of both

slides.originalNotes:
Activity assignment rule sets
Each assignable entity has ONO rule sets. Assignment is the process of running these rules. Assignment is complete when either the object has a user and group or there are no more rules left to run.
Assignment rules are not used when a user (or queue) and group are specified by the user who is creating or reassigning the item. Assignment rules are used only when there is a group but no specified user, or when there is neither a specified group nor user.
Under the Default Group Activity Assignment Rules the activity is assigned to a user within the group using round-robin.
Under the Global Activity Assignment Rules an activity is assigned to the person who holds a specific role on policy transaction or on the policy as a whole, can be the underwriter or maybe the producer.
slides.notes:

slides.originalNotes:
Auto Assign() example
In the base configuration, Policy Center provides the plugin implementation gw.plugin.preupdate.impl.PreUpd ateHandlerlmpl. By default, this plugin implementation class collects all inserted and updated beans, as well as accounts and jobs if any assignments changed. Any exception cause the bounding database transaction to roll back, effectively undoing the update.

Guidewire Integration Guide has more information on Preupdate Handler Plugin.

slides.originalNotes:
Common assignment strategies
This slide describes some common approaches to object assignment, but it is by no means an exhaustive discussion of how assignment can or is done.
slides.notes:
Common assignment strategies
This slide describes some common approaches to object assignment, but it is by no means an exhaustive discussion of how assignment can or is done.
slides.ocrText:
i Common assignment strategies Ga

« Assign to a specific group and then round-robin among users

« Round robin ignores users that lack permission to own the object

« Round-robin functionality can be configured to take into account user workload/load factors
¢ Assign to a specific group and user

¢ Assign to a queue

slides.originalNotes:
Common assignment methods
PolicyCenter Rules Guide has more information on assignment in PolicyCenter.  

Guidewire divides the assignment methods into the following general categories:
• Queue Assignment
• Immediate Assignment
• Condition-based Assignment
• Round-robin Assignment
• Dynamic Assignment

• Queue Assignment
• Immediate Assignment

slides.originalNotes:
Always exit rule when configuring assignment rules
After you have assigned an object to its final group, there is no reason to continue in the rule set. Furthermore, there is some risk that a rule further down in the list will reassign your entity to another group in a way that you do not want. Therefore, it is important to execute the actions-exit() method as soon as the object has an appropriate group assignment- By wrapping the assignment method inside an  IF command, you will exit the rule set if and only if the assignment is successful. It is best practice to use this approach for every assignment method in your assignment rule sets- 

In the example, Policy Center executes the assign() method for a given activity. If the method is able to assign the activity to a group and user (in this case, group supervisor), then the method returns true and the rule set is exited. If the method is unable to assign the activity to the group, then the method returns false, and execution proceeds with the next assignment rule.

The following list describe the methods that you can add as an action for a rule to tell Policy Center what to do next.
actions-exit - this is the simplest version. Policy Center stops processing the rule set as soon as it encounters this action. 
actions-exit After – this action causes Policy Center to stop processing the rule set after processing any child rules.
actions-exitTo Next – his action causes Policy Center to stop processing the current rule and immediately go to the next peer rule. The next peer rule is one that is at the same level in the hierarchy. This is likely to be used only rarely within very complicated action sections.
actions-exitToNextParent - this action causes Policy Center to stop processing the current rule and immediately go to the next rule at the level of the parent rule. It thus skips any child rules of the current rule.
actions-exitToNextRoot- this action causes PolicyCenter to stop processing the current rule and immediately go tothe next rule at the toplevel. It thus skips any other rules in the entire top-level branch containing this rule-

slides.originalNotes:
Assigning to a specific group
The activity is assigned directly to the Los Angeles Branch UW group. If the assignment is successful, then the rule set is exited. If for some reason the assignment is unsuccessful (for example, the group does not exist), then the next assignment rule is executed.

The find roup() method is defined in a suggested enhancement to the Activity entity. The enhancement provides the find Group() query method,  which returns a group that matches a group name. The At Most One Row method ensures result Obj returns only unique item, otherwise an exception will be thrown.
slides.notes:
Assigning to a specific group
The activity is assigned directly to the Los Angeles Branch UW group. If the assignment is successful, then the rule set is exited. If for some reason the assignment is unsuccessful (for example, the group does not exist), then the next assignment rule is executed.

The find roup() method is defined in a suggested enhancement to the Activity entity. The enhancement provides the find Group() query method,  which returns a group that matches a group name. The At Most One Row method ensures result Obj returns only unique item, otherwise an exception will be thrown.

slides.originalNotes:
Assigning to group by type and location
It is common to assign objects by group type and location. For example, assign activity to inspector in same region as policy.

Typically, the third parameter is set to false. In most cases, youwant the method to check all descendent groups, not just the immediate children.

Typically, the fourth parameter is set to either null orto the group which the object is currently assigned to, which is retrieved from "
<entitY>.CurrentAssignment.Assi gnedGroup".
Set to null, which defaults to the root group which represents the entire company, when this rule expects to use the top-level of the group hierarchy as the starting point- This will be almost all of the time in the Global Assignment rule sets.
Set to <entitY>.CurrentAssignment.A ssignedGroup when you want to use any previous group assignment as the starting point. Rules in the Default Group Assignment rule sets always pass this value to assignment functions  (whether assigning to users or groups.)

slides.ocrText:
i Assigning to group by type and location

¢ Assigns to group:
* Of specified group type...
* ...whose region covers specified address...
* ...including only direct child groups or all descendent groups...
* ...beginning with children of specified group
+ Specified group typically set to null or <entity>.AssignedGroup
¢ Using round-robin

¢ Syntax: object.assignGroupByLocation (
groupType, address, directChildrenOnly, group)

if (activity.assignGroupByLocation (
typekey.GroupType.IC_HOMEOFFICEADMIN, policyPeriod.PolicyAddress.Address, false, null)) {
actions.exit()

}

slides.originalNotes:
Step I: Identify candidate groups
First, the assignGroupByLocation method identifies the "candidate groups" for assignment. It does this by identifying the children of a given group. (This could be either just immediate child groups, if the third parameter is true, or all descendent groups, if the third parameter is false.)

In the example, the assignGroupByLocation method is to locate all descendent groups of the root group, Enigma Fire Casualty Insurance. Therefore, all groups within the group hierarchy are potential candidates for assignment.

slides.originalNotes:
Step 2: Filter by group type
Next, the assignGroupByLocation method filters out groups which do not have the given type.
If no group type is specified (if the first parameter is NULL), then this step is skipped.
If only one group remains, then the object is assigned to that group.
In the example, the assignGroupByLocation methodis to locate a group of type•HOMEOFFICEADMIN". There are only four groups in the Home Office Admin Services group – all other groups are eliminated.

slides.originalNotes:
Step 3: Select by location
Once groups have been eliminated by group type, a group is chosen from the survivors. The manner in which this search is conducted is discussed on the next slide.

The method looks first for a group whose region includes the location passed into the assignment function. If no group with a matching location can be found, then the method returns false.
slides.notes:

The method looks first for a group whose region includes the location passed into the assignment function. If no group with a matching location can be found, then the method returns false.

slides.originalNotes:
Configuring location selection
Regions are typically made up of one zone type, but you can create them from multiple types.

Each zone type within a country is matched in assignment rules based on the regionMatchOrder property. In the US example from the screenshot, region matching is done by zip, then county, then state. Since there is no regionMatchOrder property on the city zone, city is not considered for location matching. (City may be used on other parts of the application.)
slides.notes:
Configuring location selection
Regions are typically made up of one zone type, but you can create them from multiple types.

Each zone type within a country is matched in assignment rules based on the regionMatchOrder property. In the US example from the screenshot, region matching is done by zip, then county, then state. Since there is no regionMatchOrder property on the city zone, city is not considered for location matching. (City may be used on other parts of the application.)

slides.originalNotes:
What if group assignment fails?
After global assignment rules have been executed, the assignment engine checks to see whether the object was assigned to a group. If the object has not been assigned to a group, then it is assigned to a dummy user called Default Owner and to the root group of the hierarchy. (If the object was assigned to a group,  then assignment proceeds as normal.)
Default Owner is a dummy user used for objects that fail group assignment. You cannot log on asDefault Owner, and there is typically extra overhead in identifying items assigned to Default Owner and reassigning them to a real user. In general, it is considered bad practice tohave a rule set that results in objects being assigned to the Default Owner.
slides.notes:
What if group assignment fails?
After global assignment rules have been executed, the assignment engine checks to see whether the object was assigned to a group. If the object has not been assigned to a group, then it is assigned to a dummy user called Default Owner and to the root group of the hierarchy. (If the object was assigned to a group,  then assignment proceeds as normal.)
Default Owner is a dummy user used for objects that fail group assignment. You cannot log on asDefault Owner, and there is typically extra overhead in identifying items assigned to Default Owner and reassigning them to a real user. In general, it is considered bad practice tohave a rule set that results in objects being assigned to the Default Owner.

slides.originalNotes:
Assigning to a specific user
Note that this method technically assigns both the group and the user (as both parameters are required). However, you can regard this method as a user assignment method. In most cases, when you are selecting a particular user, the group that the user is in is determined by default. This method could be called from either global or default group rules. If it is called from global rules, then the object will have an assigned user at the end of execution of that rule set, and therefore the Default Group rule set will not execute

Assigning to a user and any group
This method can be called from either global or default group rules. If it is called from globa  rules, then the object will have an assigned user at the end of execution of that rule set, and therefore the Default Group rule set will not execute.
slides.notes:
Assigning to a user and any group
This method can be called from either global or default group rules. If it is called from globa  rules, then the object will have an assigned user at the end of execution of that rule set, and therefore the Default Group rule set will not execute.

i Assigning to a user and any group

¢ Assigns object to a user and any group that the user belongs to

¢ Syntax:
object.assignUserAndDefaultGroup (User)

actions.exit()

slides.originalNotes:
What if user assignment fails?
After default group assignment rules have been executed, the assignment engine checks to see if the object was assigned to a user. There are three possible
outcomes:
If the object was assigned to a user, then the assignment is done.
If the object was not assigned to a user, but it was assigned to a new group, then the default group rules are re- executed. This behavior can be used to have an object travel between groups before being assigned to a user at the appropriate group level. 
If the object was not assigned to either a user or a new group, then the object is assigned to the supervisor of the current group. This assignment behavior is inherent to the assignment engine and cannot be modified. 
Logging messages at the WARN level identify when an object cannot be assigned to a user within the Default Group rule set.
slides.notes:

outcomes:
If the object was assigned to a user, then the assignment is done.
If the object was not assigned to a user, but it was assigned to a new group, then the default group rules are re- executed. This behavior can be used to have an object travel between groups before being assigned to a user at the appropriate group level. 
If the object was not assigned to either a user or a new group, then the object is assigned to the supervisor of the current group. This assignment behavior is inherent to the assignment engine and cannot be modified. 
Logging messages at the WARN level identify when an object cannot be assigned to a user within the Default Group rule set.

Question G

,~ — Whatis the difference between primary and secondary assignment?

¢
4
¢

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer Gi

,~ — What is the difference between primary and secondary assignment?

¢
4
¢

In primary assignment, a single user is assigned ownership of the assigned object. In
secondary assignment, one or more users are assigned to roles with respect to the
assigned object.

SS Se ee eee eo

Question G

,~ — When an activity is assigned by rules, which two rule sets are typically
oo executed? In what order?

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer Gi

,~ — When an activity is assigned by rules, which two rule sets are typically
Fa executed? In what order?

First, global rules are executed. Then, default group rules are executed.

SS Se ee eee eo

oo assignment rules being executed?

¢

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer

,~ — Under what circumstances can an activity be assigned without

Fa assignment rules being executed?

¢

Question G

,- — Why are assignment methods always inside i‘ statements in assignment

7 rules?
0 ! ’
7

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer Gi

,- — Why are assignment methods always inside i statements in assignment
Fa rules?
¢

Assignment methods are always inside if statements because they might fail. For
example, an assignGroup method may not be able to find the specified group.

If the assignment succeeds, then the if statement causes control of flow to execute an
actions.exit() statement, which exits execution from the rule set.

If the assignment fails, then the actions.exit() statement is skipped and execution
proceeds to the next rule.

SS Se ee eee eo

Question G

,~ — What is the Default Owner of an object?

¢
4
¢

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer Gi

,~ — What is the Default Owner of an object?
¢
4
¢

Default Owner is a dummy user that objects are assigned to when global assignment
rules fail to assign the object to a group.
